name: Orphan drug candidate blossoms in Japan
introduction: A novel treatment for the viral disease CMV viremia, TAK-620 (maribavir), has generated positive results in the Phase III SOLSTICE trial.
content:
A novel treatment for the viral disease CMV viremia, TAK-620 (maribavir), has generated positive results in the Phase III SOLSTICE trial.

Japanese pharma major Takeda Pharmaceutical (TYO: 4502) presented the data during a Presidential Symposium at the annual meeting of the European Society for Blood and Marrow Transplantation (EBMT).

Results from a subgroup analysis show greater than three times as many (62.8%) transplant recipients in the test group achieved clearance after eight weeks, compared with those who received investigator assigned treatment.

Transplant recipients in the subgroup receiving maribavir exhibited lower incidence of treatment-related toxicities common with conventional antiviral therapies, Takeda said.

Overall, 67% of those treated with maribavir experienced side effects, and serious adverse events including diarrhea and renal failure were much more common in this group, compared with those given Valcyte (valganciclovir).

However, given the severity of the condition and the lack of alternatives, regulators will likely not consider that an impediment to approval.

Maribavir development

The CMV virus is very widespread, and is normally safely controlled by a healthy immune system. For those who receive a transplant, immunosuppressants can result in a flare up of the virus, leading to serious disease.

Maribavir, an orphan drug-designated antiviral agent, is currently the only investigational therapy in development for this patient population.

Originally part of ViroPharma’s pipeline, the therapy was picked up by Shire, and subsequently by Takeda via its $64 billion acquisition of the rare disease specialist.

The detailed results build on previously released top-line data showing the SOLSTICE trial met its primary efficacy endpoint.

Rafael Duarte, of Madrid-based Hospital Universitario Puerta de Hierro, said: “Transplant recipients with CMV infections resistant to conventional antiviral therapies are some of the hardest to treat.”

He added: “We believe these data are important as they build on previously presented results supporting the potential of maribavir, which, if approved, could transform the management of CMV in these patients."
